text: after 18 years there's still no end in
sight and little to show for what is now
America's longest war the conflict has
dogged three u.s. administrations and
their messages have shifted with public
opinion great nations do not fight
endless wars he wants out and he thinks
the exit is through talks with the
Taliban so how close is the United
States to a deal well there's been a
series of unlikely meetings at a
luxurious resort in Qatar at the
negotiating table both sides agreed on a
framework for a peace deal the US would
withdraw international forces from
Afghanistan and the Taliban wouldn't
allow jihadist groups to operate in the
country and as for the Afghan government
well they haven't had a say because
they've been shut out of discussions
Afghan officials are furious
they say the talks legitimize the
Taliban and undermine their authority
these guys have a lot on their hands it
is a shame for world order to bow to
terror let's put it simple do you think
the United States is right or wrong in
leaving the Afghan government out of
talks so the longer the Afghan
government is held out of the direct
negotiations larger the problems I think
in it in encompasses and frankly when
you look at past successful negotiations
you had to have the government sit down
with insurgents to hammer out the vast
majority of the details
and until that happens it's hard for
anybody really to say the prospects for
a successful settlement or hi and so
what happens if the United States of the
Taliban reach a deal but the Taliban
still refuses to speak to the government
of Afghanistan you don't really have a
peace deal at that point what you may
potentially have is a situation where
the u.s. is essentially creating this
fig leaf for withdrawing from the
country the US envoy recently spent time
in Afghanistan trying to smooth things
over
and now the Afghan government has set up
a council that plans to exchange views
with the Taliban in Qatar later this
month elections in Afghanistan were
supposed to take place on April 20th but
in order to give peace talks a chance
they've been postponed until September
